dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but it makes you wonder, like, what *is* our actual strategy here? Because this feels very, uh, reactive.

dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! And it just shows how, um, China's not really doing that "patient statecraft" thing anymore that Kissinger used to talk about.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! And it just shows how, um, China's not really doing that patient statecraft thing anymore that Kissinger used to talk about.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Henry Kissinger school of Oriental inscrutability peddled the canard that Chinese leaders epitomized a unique ability to conduct long-term, patient statecraft. Nobody told Chinas president, Xi Jinping, or his wolf-warrior diplomats to be patient.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: No, Xi Jinping seems to have, like, thrown that out the window. He's actually goading countries to resist China, which is, you know, the opposite of patient.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: No, Xi Jinping seems to have, like, thrown that out the window. He's actually goading countries to resist China, which is, you know, the opposite of patient.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: If Xi had been more patient, much of East Asia would have been dominated by China within the next decade. Instead, he is goading countries around the region to resist China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Totally. And it’s a big shift from Deng Xiaoping’s dictum, remember? "Bide your time, hide your strength." Xi's just, uh, doing the opposite.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Totally. And it's a big shift from Deng Xiaoping's dictum, remember? Bide your time, hide your strength. Xi's just, uh, doing the opposite.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Whatever happened to Deng Xiaopings dictum that China should bide its time and hide its strength? ... Yet Xi has effectively thrown Deng onto the dust heap of history, reaching back to the past in nurturing his neo-Maoist policies.

dialogue_turns.tts_text: He's gone full neo-Maoist, hasn't he? I mean, look at how he's stifling dissent. The Winnie the Pooh thing, the hammering of Hong Kong...
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Yet Xi has effectively thrown Deng onto the dust heap of history, reaching back to the past in nurturing his neo-Maoist policies. The hammering of Hong Kong is yet more evidence of the urge to smother dissent that has long been common in other peripheral areas, Tibet and Xinjiang.

dialogue_turns.text: Oh, the Hong Kong thing is just brutal. Arresting people for holding up blank sheets of paper? After guaranteeing freedom of speech? That's just... I don't even know.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, the Hong Kong thing is just brutal. Arresting people for holding up blank sheets of paper? After guaranteeing freedom of speech? That's just... I don't even know.

dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild. And it really paints a picture of a China that's taking on, like, multiple enemies at once, which hasn't happened since nineteen forty nine.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, what do you make of the comparison to, like, Christopher Clark's "Sleepwalkers," you know, stumbling into WWI?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, what do you make of the comparison to, like, Christopher Clark's Sleepwalkers, you know, stumbling into W W I?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Historian Christopher Clarks The Sleepwalkers portrays a half-awake Europe stumbling into the horror of World War I. Much has been written comparing the world that Clark describes with the brewing Sino-U.S. conflict.
